Merge pull request #248 from ReneeVandervelde/fix/completable-type

Remove generic type declaration for Completable bindings.

Remove generic type declaration for Completable bindings.

Remove the unecessary generic type <T> from the kotlin extensions for
binding to Completable chains. The type declared in the signature is not
being used in the function, and doesn't make sense on a Completable, so
this looks like a copy/paste error.
This fixes the following error, when not specifying a type:

    Type inference failed: Not enough information to infer parameter T in fun <T> Completable.bindUntilEvent(owner: LifecycleOwner, event: Lifecycle.Event): Completable

Merge pull request #174 from trello/dlew/simplify-implementation

Greatly simplify implementation

Consolidated everything into LifecycleTransformer

There was no need for multiple Transformer classes, as everything
comes down to waiting for a single event from a source Observable.
As such, we can make LifecycleTransformer a concrete class that
listens to a second Observable (and the RxLifecycle methods
just feed into it).

Use RxLifecycle in all our tests

(Rather than accessing the classes directly)

Merge pull request #167 from trello/dlew/rxjava2

Upgrade to RxJava 2
Use Completable.ambArray()

Removed references to specific Transformers in javadoc

Now that we have just one omni-transformer

Upgrade to RxJava 2

The goal here is just to start the big transition, I'm sure there are
lots of little polishes/improvements we can do once this is in.

Some of the bigger changes:

- Removed dependency on RxBinding since there is no RxJava 2-based
  RxBinding yet. Implementing our own ViewDetachesOnSubscribe was
  not that bad.

- Rolled all Transformers into a single LifecycleTransformer, now that
  we can do so (due to composition-friendly interfaces).

Binding outside lifecycle causes instant completion

Moved null-checking up to front of methods

Also added a bunch of tests that the null checks are working

Binding outside lifecycle causes instant completion

Before, it would throw an exception, which doesn't make as much sense - if
the logic worked out such that you bound outside the lifecycle, that prboably
meant that you just don't want the subscription to occur outside the
lifecycle, so it should end immediately.

Removed unnecessary warnings from docs

Now that we're using takeUntil it's not an issue anymore.

Merge pull request #14 from trello/dlew/take-until

Converted OperatorSubscribeUntil -> takeUntil
Updated to latest Android gradle plugin/RxJava

Lowered minSdkVersion to 14

Because why not

Converted OperatorSubscribeUntil -> takeUntil

There was one key problem with OperatorSubscribeUntil, which is that
it had the potential to be incompatible with other Operators. This
required you to be careful about when you call it, which isn't great
for a library.

Switching to takeUntil means that onCompleted will be called when
the sequence completes due to a lifecycle event. But that's alright;
in most cases it won't change anything. Also, if someone *does*
need to terminate without onCompleted, they can manually handle
the Subscription and unsubscribe themselves.

Use TestSubscriber for tests

This makes it easier to test certain Subscription states.
